etymologies: mid 17th century; earliest use found in Thomas Stanley (1625–1678), poet and classical scholar. From ancient Greek πειραστικός of the nature of trying, tentative, especially with reference to dialectic from πειράζειν to try (from πεῖρα trial, attempt, endeavour) + -τικός, suffix forming adjectives from verbs

definitions: Involving, or performing, an experiment; speculative, experimental, tentative.
